original: Dīgha Nikāya 23
analyzed: dīgha nikāya
translated: Long Discourses with Ānanda

original: Pāyāsisutta
analyzed: pāyāsi sutta
translated: With Pāyāsi

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā kumārakassapo kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena setabyā nāma kosalānaṁ nagaraṁ tadavasari.
analyzed: ekam samayam āyasmā kumārakassapaḥ kosalesu cārikam caramānaḥ mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi yena setabyā nāma kosalānam nagaram tat avasari
translated: Once, when the Venerable Kumāra Kassapa was wandering in the Kosalan country with a large company of about five hundred monks, he eventually arrived at the Kosalan city of Setavyā.

original: Tatra sudaṁ āyasmā kumārakassapo setabyāyaṁ viharati uttarena setabyaṁ siṁsapāvane.
analyzed: tatra sudam āyasmā kumārakassapo setabyāyam viharati uttarena setabyam sisapāvane
translated: There he lived in a forest of simsapa trees north of Setavyā.

original: Tena kho pana samayena pāyāsi rājañño setabyaṁ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṁ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṁ sadhaññaṁ rājabhoggaṁ raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṁ rājadāyaṁ brahmadeyyaṁ.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena pāyāsi rājaññaḥ setabyam ajjhāvasati sattussadam sa tiṇa kaṭṭhodakam sa dhaññam rāja bhoggam raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnam rāja dāyam brahmadeyya
translated: At that time the Kosalan King Pasenadi had given to the brahmin Pāyāsi the district town of Setavyā as a royal gift and a brahminical gift.

original: 1. Pāyāsirājaññavatthu
analyzed: pāyāsi rājañña vatthu
translated: The Story of the Brahmin Pāyāsi

original: Tena kho pana samayena pāyāsissa rājaññassa evarūpaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ uppannaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena pāyāsissa rājaññassa evarūpam pāpakam diṭṭhi gatam uppannam hoti
translated: At that time the brahmin Pāyāsi had this pernicious view:

original: “itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko”ti.
analyzed: iti pi natthi paraḥ lokaḥ natthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: “As I understand the Dhamma taught by the brahmins, one who kills living beings … and holds to wrong view — when his body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a good destination, a heavenly world.”

original: Assosuṁ kho setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā:
analyzed: assosum kho setabyakā brāhmaṇa gahapatikā
translated: The brahmin householders of Setavyā heard:

original: “samaṇo khalu bho kumārakassapo samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno
analyzed: samaṇaḥ khalu bho kumārakassapaḥ samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakaḥ kosalesu cārikam caramānaḥ
translated: “The ascetic Kumāra-Kassapa, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama,

original: mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi setabyaṁ anuppatto setabyāyaṁ
analyzed: mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi setabyam an uppattaḥ setabyāya
translated: who is wandering on a tour of Kośala with a large company of five hundred monks,

original: viharati uttarena setabyaṁ siṁsapāvane.
analyzed: viharati uttarena setabyam sisapāvane
translated: has arrived at Setavyā and is staying to the north of Setavyā in the Siṁsapā Forest.

original: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ kumārakassapaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
analyzed: tam khaḥ pana bhavantam kumāra kassapam evam kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ
translated: And this good report about him has spread:

original: ‘paṇḍito byatto medhāvī bahussuto cittakathī kalyāṇapaṭibhāno vuddho ceva arahā ca.
analyzed: paṇḍitaḥ byattaḥ medhāvī bahu ssutaḥ citta kathī kalyāṇa paṭibhānaḥ vuddhaḥ ca iva arahā ca
translated: ‘He is wise, experienced, intelligent, learned, articulate, and cultured; he is an arahant.’

original: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṁ arahataṁ dassanaṁ hotī’”ti.
analyzed: sādhu kho pana tathārūpānam arahatam dassanam hoti iti
translated: It is good to see such arahants.”

original: Atha kho setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā uttarenamukhā gacchanti yena siṁsapāvanaṁ.
analyzed: atha kho setabyakāḥ brāhmaṇa gahapatikā setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅgha saṅghī gaṇībhūtā uttarenamukhāḥ gacchanti yena sisapāvana
translated: Then the brahmin householders of Setavyā left Setavyā and went to the Siṁsapā Forest.

original: Tena kho pana samayena pāyāsi rājañño uparipāsāde divāseyyaṁ upagato hoti.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena pāyāsi rājaññaḥ upari pāsāde divāseyyam upagataḥ hoti
translated: At that time the aristocrat Pāyāsi was lying on the upper terrace for his midday rest.

original: Addasā kho pāyāsi rājañño setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūte uttarenamukhe gacchante yena siṁsapāvanaṁ,
analyzed: addasā kho pāyāsi rājañño setabyake brāhmaṇa gahapatike setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅgha saṅghī gaṇībhūte uttarenamukhe gacchante yena sisapāvana
translated: He saw the brahmin householders of Setavyā leaving Setavyā in groups and pairs, heading north to the Simsapa Forest.

original: disvā khattaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: disvā khattam āmantesi
translated: Seeing this, he asked his steward,

original: “kiṁ nu kho, bho khatte, setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā uttarenamukhā gacchanti yena siṁsapāvanan”ti?
analyzed: kim nu khalu bho khatte setabyakā brāhmaṇa gahapatikā setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅgha saṅghī gaṇībhūtā uttarenamukhā gacchanti yena sisapāvananti
translated: “Steward, why are the brahmin householders of Setavyā leaving Setavyā in groups and pairs, heading north to the Simsapa Forest?”

original: “Atthi kho, bho, samaṇo kumārakassapo, samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako kosalesu cārikaṁ
analyzed: atthi kho bho samaṇaḥ kumārakassapaḥ samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako kosalesu cārika
translated: “Sir, there is a Sakyan named Kassapa who has gone forth from the Sakyan clan.

original: caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi setabyaṁ anuppatto
analyzed: caramānaḥ mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi setabyam an uppattaḥ
translated: He has arrived at Setavyā with a large Saṅgha of five hundred bhikkhus.

original: setabyāyaṁ viharati uttarena setabyaṁ siṁsapāvane.
analyzed: viharati uttarena setabyam sisapāvane
translated: He is staying to the north of Setavyā in the Simsapa Forest.

original: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ kumārakassapaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
analyzed: tam khaḥ pana bhavantam kumāra kassapam evam kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ
translated: Now a good report of Master Kassapa has been spread to this effect:

original: ‘paṇḍito byatto medhāvī bahussuto cittakathī kalyāṇapaṭibhāno vuddho ceva arahā cā’ti.
analyzed: paṇḍitaḥ byattaḥ medhāvī bahu ssutaḥ citta kathī kalyāṇa paṭibhānaḥ vuddhaḥ ca iva arahā ca ati
translated: ‘He is learned, knowledgeable, intelligent, wise, articulate, and polished; he is a good speaker, able to preach the Dhamma with fluent delivery, with polished words and phrases. He is mature, long gone forth, aged, venerable, advanced in years, and at the last stage of life.’

original: Tamete bhavantaṁ kumārakassapaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamantī”ti.
analyzed: tam ete bhavantam kumārakassapam dassanāya upasaṅkamanti iti
translated: That’s why they’re going to see Master Kassapa.”

original: “Tena hi, bho khatte, yena setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike evaṁ vadehi:
analyzed: tena hi bho khatte yena setabyakā brāhmaṇa gahapatikā tena upasaṅkama upasaṅkamitvā setabyake brāhmaṇa gahapatike evam vadehi
translated: “Well then, Khattiya, go to the brahmin householders of Setavyā and say to them:

original: ‘pāyāsi, bho, rājañño evamāha—
analyzed: bho rājaññaḥ evam āha
translated: ‘The aristocrat Pāyāsi says this:

original: āgamentu kira bhavanto, pāyāsipi rājañño samaṇaṁ kumārakassapaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’ti.
analyzed: āgamentu kira bhavantaḥ pāyāsipi rājañño samaṇam kumārakassapam dassanāya upasaṅkamissati iti
translated: Please come, sirs, for the aristocrat Pāyāsi will also go to see the ascetic Kumāra Kassapa.’

original: Purā samaṇo kumārakassapo setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike bāle abyatte saññāpeti:
analyzed: purā samaṇaḥ kumārakassapaḥ setabyake brāhmaṇa gahapatike bāle abyatte saññāpeti
translated: Before the ascetic Kumāra Kassapa misleads the brahmin householders of Setavyā, the foolish, incompetent man,

original: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’ti.
analyzed: iti pi atthi paraḥ lokaḥ atthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ atthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: saying: “There is another world, there are spontaneously born beings, and there is fruit and result of good and bad deeds.”

original: Natthi hi, bho khatte, paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko”ti.
analyzed: natthi hi bho khatte paraḥ lokaḥ natthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: For there is no other world, there are no spontaneously born beings, and there is no fruit or result of good or bad deeds.”

original: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho so khattā pāyāsissa rājaññassa paṭissutvā yena setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike etadavoca:
analyzed: eva bhoti kho saḥ khattā pāyāsissa rājaññassa paṭissutvā yena setabyakā brāhmaṇa gahapatikā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā setabyake brāhmaṇa gahapatike etat avoca
translated: “Yes, dear sir,” he replied, and he went to the brahmin householders of Setavyā and told them:

original: “pāyāsi, bho, rājañño evamāha, āgamentu kira bhavanto, pāyāsipi rājañño samaṇaṁ kumārakassapaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī”ti.
analyzed: pāyāsi bho rājañño evam āha āgamentu kira bhavantaḥ rājañño samaṇam kumārakassapam dassanāya upasaṅkamissati iti
translated: “Pāyāsi the brahmin says this: ‘Let the honorable ones come, Pāyāsi the brahmin will also go to see the recluse Kumāra Kassapa.’“

original: Atha kho pāyāsi rājañño setabyakehi brāhmaṇagahapatikehi parivuto yena siṁsapāvanaṁ
analyzed: atha kho pāyāsi rājaññaḥ setabyakehi brāhmaṇa gahapatikehi parivutaḥ yena sisapāvana
translated: Then Pāyāsi the brahmin, attended by the brahmin householders of Setavyā,🔽went to the Simsapa Forest.

original: yenāyasmā kumārakassapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā kumārakassapena saddhiṁ
analyzed: yena āyasmā kumārakassapaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā kumārakassapena saddhi
translated: He went to the venerable Kumāra Kassapa, and after paying homage to him,

original: sammodi, sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.🔽Setabyakāpi kho brāhmaṇagahapatikā appekacce āyasmantaṁ kumārakassapaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu;
analyzed: sammodi sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi  setabyakā api kho brāhmaṇa gahapatikāḥ appa ekacce āyasmantam kumārakassapam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdisu
translated: he sat down at one side.🔽Some of the brahmin householders of Setavyā paid homage to the venerable Kumāra Kassapa and sat down at one side;

original: appekacce āyasmatā kumārakassapena saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu;
analyzed: appa ekacce āyasmatā kumārakassapena saddhim sammodisu
translated: some exchanged greetings with him and sat down at one side;

original: sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam
translated: and when this courteous and amiable talk was finished, they sat down to one side.

original: Appekacce yenāyasmā kumārakassapo tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.🔽Appekacce nāmagottaṁ sāvetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
analyzed: appa ekacce yena ayasmā kumārakassapo tena añjalim paṇāmetvā ekamantam nisīdisu  appa ekacce nāma gottam sāvetvā ekamantam
translated: Some of them bowed down to Venerable Kumāra Kassapa and then sat down to one side.🔽Some of them exchanged greetings with him and then sat down to one side.

original: Appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
analyzed: appa ekacce tuṇhībhūtāḥ ekamantam
translated: Some of them kept silent and then sat down to one side.

original: 2. Natthikavāda
analyzed: natthikavāda
translated: The view that nothing exists

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho pāyāsi rājañño āyasmantaṁ kumārakassapaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho pāyāsi rājaññaḥ āyasmantam kumārakassapam etat avoca
translated: When they were seated, Pāyāsi said to Kumāra Kassapa,

original: “ahañhi, bho kassapa, evaṁvādī evaṁdiṭṭhī:
analyzed: aham hi bho kassapa eva vādī eva diṭṭhī
translated: “Master Kassapa, I hold this view, this opinion,

analyzed: iti pi natthi paraḥ lokaḥ natthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: that ‘there is no other world, there are no spontaneously reborn beings, there is no fruit or result of good or bad deeds.’”

analyzed: na aha rājaññaḥ eva vādim eva diṭṭhim addasam vā assosim vā
translated: “Well now, Prince, I have never seen or heard that anyone has said this.

original: Kathañhi nāma evaṁ vadeyya:

translated: How could one say this?

original: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’ti?
analyzed: iti pi natthi paraḥ lokaḥ natthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: ‘There is no other world, there are no spontaneously reborn beings, there is no fruit or result of good or bad deeds’?

original: 2.1. Candimasūriyaupamā
analyzed: candima sūriyā aupamā
translated: The similes of the moon and the sun

original: Tena hi, rājañña, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi, yathā te khameyya, tathā naṁ byākareyyāsi.
analyzed: tena hi rājañña tat na eva itthā paṭipucchissāmi yathā te khameyya tathā nam byākareyyāsi
translated: “Well then, Prince, I will ask you about this in return, and you may answer as you like.

original: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, rājañña,
analyzed: tam kim maññasi rājañña
translated: What do you think, Prince?

original: ime candimasūriyā imasmiṁ vā loke parasmiṁ vā, devā vā te manussā vā”ti?
analyzed: ime candima sūriyāḥ imasmin vā loke parasmin vā devāḥ vā te manussāḥ vāti
translated: Are the sun and moon in this world or in another world? Are they gods or human beings?”

analyzed: ime bho kassapa candima sūriyā parasmin loke na imasmi devā te na manussā ati
translated: “Master Kassapa, the sun and moon are in another world; they are gods, not human beings.”

original: “Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu—
analyzed: iminā api kho te rājañña pariyāyena evam hotu
translated: “In this way, Prince, you should not say thus:

analyzed: iti pi atthi paraḥ lokaḥ atthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ atthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: ‘Thus, there is no other world, there are no spontaneously reborn beings, there is no fruit or result of good or bad deeds.’“

original: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
analyzed: kiñca api bhavam kassapaḥ evam āha atha kho evam me ettha hoti
translated: “Although Master Kassapa says this, still I think thus:

analyzed: iti pi natthi paraḥ lokaḥ natthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: ‘Thus, there is no other world, there are no spontaneously reborn beings, there is no fruit or result of good or bad deeds.’“

analyzed: atthi pana rājañña pariyāyaḥ yena te pariyāyena evam hoti

original: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti?
analyzed: iti pi natthi paraḥ lokaḥ natthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: “‘There is no other world, there are no beings spontaneously reborn, there is no fruit or result of good or bad deeds’?”

translated: “Master Kassapa, I have friends and colleagues, relatives and blood-kinsmen who are murderers, thieves, adulterers, liars, and slicers of bondsmen, slaves, and servants.

translated: when I know that

analyzed: na dāni ime imamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhahissanti iti tya aham upasaṅkamitvā evam vadāmi
translated: ‘they will not recover from this sickness,’ I go to them and say:

translated: ‘There are, masters, some recluses and brahmins who declare and believe

analyzed: ye te pāṇa atipātī adinna ādāyī kāmesu micchā cārī musā vādī pisuṇa vācā pharusa vācā samphappalāpī
translated: “Those who kill living creatures …

original: abhijjhālū byāpannacittā micchādiṭṭhī, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ

translated: There are the sun and moon, and there are those who see the sun and moon.

translated: ‘Who has told you, Master Kassapa,

translated: We do not believe that

translated: there are gods of the Thirty-three, or that they live so long and enjoy such prosperity.”

translated: Those ascetics and Brahmins who resort to remote jungle-thicket resting places in the forest … purify the divine eye.

original: Te dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena imañceva lokaṁ passanti parañca satte ca opapātike.
analyzed: te dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena iman ca eva lokam passanti param ca satte ca opapātike
translated: With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, they see this world and the next world, beings passing away and arising:

analyzed: evam ca kho rājañña paraḥ lokaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: This is the way the other world can be known.

translated: In this way too, Prince, you can believe:

translated: ‘There is another world, there are spontaneously born beings, there is fruit and result of good and evil deeds.’“

original: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:

translated: “Although Master Kassapa says this, still the idea occurs to me:

translated: ‘There is no other world, there are no spontaneously born beings, there is no fruit or result of good or evil deeds.’“🔽“But, Prince, there is a way in which one can understand:

translated: “There is, Kassapa.”

analyzed: yathā katham viya  idha āha bho kassapa passāmi samaṇa brāhmaṇe sīlavante kalyāṇa dhamme jīvitu kāme a maritu kāme sukha kāme dukkha paṭikūle
translated: “How is that, Prince?”

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bho kassapa, evaṁ hoti—
analyzed: tassa bho kassapa evam hoti
translated: “Master Kassapa, I see some ascetics and brahmins who are virtuous and of good character, who desire to live and do not desire to die, who desire pleasure and abhor pain.🔽I think:

translated: “After death, we will be reborn in a good destination, in a heavenly world.”🔽Then they would eat food without fear, without hesitation.

analyzed: ca kho ime bhontaḥ samaṇa brāhmaṇā sīlavantaḥ kalyāṇa dhammā na evam jānanti
translated: But since these good ascetics and brahmins do not know this,

analyzed: itas naḥ matānam seyyaḥ bhavissati iti tasmai ime bhonto samaṇa brāhmaṇā sīlavantaḥ kalyāṇa dhammā jīvitu kāmā a maritu kāmā sukha kāmā dukkha paṭikūlā attānam na mārenti  ayam pi kho bho kassapa pariyāyaḥ yena me pariyāyena evam hoti
translated: ‘After death, it will be better for us.’ That is why these good secluded contemplatives and brahmans, who are virtuous and of good character, who desire to live and do not desire to die, who desire happiness and recoil from pain, do not kill themselves.

original: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
analyzed: iti pi natthi paraḥ lokaḥ natthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: This is another way, Master Kassapa, in which it can be understood how there are single things in the world that are desirable, lovely, pleasant, leading to satisfaction, and agreeable, and yet when one devotes oneself to them exclusively, they lead to harm and unhappiness.”

analyzed: pāṇinā ākoṭetha  leḍḍunā ākoṭetha
translated: “Hit him with your hands …🔽“Hit him with a clod …

original: daṇḍena ākoṭetha …
analyzed: daṇḍena ākoṭetha
translated: “Hit him with a stick …

original: satthena ākoṭetha …
analyzed: satthena ākoṭetha
translated: “Hit him with a knife …

original: odhunātha sandhunātha niddhunātha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
analyzed: odhunātha sandhunātha niddhunātha appā iva nāmassa jīvam nikkhamantam passeyyāma ati
translated: “Shake him, rock him, and toss him about, so that we can see his life-principle come out.”

original: Te taṁ purisaṁ odhunanti sandhunanti niddhunanti.
analyzed: te tam purisam odhunanti sandhunanti niddhunanti
translated: They shake him, rock him, and toss him about.

original: Nevassa mayaṁ jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passāma.
analyzed: na iva assa mayam jīvam nikkhamantam passāma
translated: But we still don’t see his life-principle come out.

original: Tassa tadeva cakkhu hoti te rūpā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.🔽Tadeva sotaṁ hoti te saddā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.🔽Tadeva ghānaṁ hoti te gandhā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: tassa tat eva cakkhu hoti te rūpā tat ca āyatanam na paṭisavedeti  tat eva sotam hoti te saddāḥ tat ca āyatanam na paṭisaveda iti  tat eva ghānam hoti te gandhā tat ca āyatanam na paṭisaveda iti
translated: He has the same eyes, the same visible forms, but he doesn’t experience that sense-sphere.🔽He has the same ears, the same sounds, but he doesn’t experience that sense-sphere.🔽He has the same nose, the same smells, but he doesn’t experience that sense-sphere.

original: Sāva jivhā hoti te rasā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: sā ava jivhā hoti te rasā tat ca āyatanam na paṭisavedeti
translated: He has the same tongue, the same tastes, but he doesn’t experience that sense-sphere.

original: Sveva kāyo hoti te phoṭṭhabbā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: su eva kāyaḥ hoti te phoṭṭhabbā tat ca āyatanam na paṭisavedeti
translated: He has the same body, the same tangibles, but he doesn’t experience that sense-sphere.

original: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: ayam pi kho bho kassapa pariyāyaḥ yena me pariyāyena evam hoti
translated: “This is another way, Master Kassapa, in which I know:

original: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
analyzed: iti pi natthi paraḥ lokaḥ natthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: ‘There is no other world, there are no spontaneously reborn beings, there is no fruit or result of good or bad deeds.’“

original: 2.9. Saṅkhadhamaupamā
analyzed: saṅkha dhamā aupamā
translated: … The Simile of the Conch-Shell

original: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi.
analyzed: tena hi rājaññaḥ upamam te karissāmi
translated: “Well now, prince, I will give you a simile.

original: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
analyzed: upamāya midhekacce viññū purisāḥ bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti
translated: For by means of a simile some wise men understand the meaning of what is said.

original: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññataro saṅkhadhamo saṅkhaṁ ādāya paccantimaṁ janapadaṁ agamāsi.🔽So yena aññataro gāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā majjhe gāmassa ṭhito tikkhattuṁ saṅkhaṁ upalāpetvā saṅkhaṁ bhūmiyaṁ nikkhipitvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: bhūta pubba rājañña aññataraḥ saṅkha dhamaḥ saṅkham ādāya paccantimam janapadam agamāsi  saḥ yena aññataraḥ gāmo tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā majjhe gāmassa ṭhitaḥ tikkhattum saṅkham upalāpetvā saṅkham bhūmiyam nikkhipitvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: Prince, once upon a time a certain conch-seller came to a town in the countryside and there he announced:🔽‘Sirs, I have brought a conch from the ocean, which has the power to dispel all misfortune.

original: Atha kho, rājañña, tesaṁ paccantajanapadānaṁ manussānaṁ etadahosi:
analyzed: atha kho rājañña tesam paccanta janapadānam manussānam etat ahosi
translated: Then the country people said to him:

original: ‘ambho kassa nu kho eso saddo evaṁrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṁmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṁmucchanīyo’ti.
analyzed: ambho kassa nu kho eso saddaḥ evarajanīyaḥ evaṅkamanīyaḥ evamadanīyaḥ evambandhanīyaḥ evamucchanīyaḥ iti
translated: ‘This conch has the power to dispel misfortune, but what is its sound like?’

original: Sannipatitvā taṁ saṅkhadhamaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: sannipatitvā tam saṅkhadhamam etat avocuḥ
translated: They gathered together and said to the conch-blower:

original: ‘ambho, kassa nu kho eso saddo evaṁrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṁmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṁmucchanīyo’ti.
analyzed: ambho kassa nu kho eso saddaḥ evarajanīyaḥ evaṅkamanīyaḥ evamadanīyaḥ evambandhanīyaḥ evamucchanīyaḥ iti
translated: ‘Hey, what is this sound that is so captivating, so delightful, so intoxicating, so compelling, so enticing?’

original: ‘Eso kho, bho, saṅkho nāma yasseso saddo evaṁrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṁmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṁmucchanīyo’ti.
analyzed: esaḥ kho bho saṅkhaḥ nāma yassa isaḥ saddaḥ eva rajanīyaḥ evaṅkamanīyaḥ evamadanīyaḥ evambandhanīyaḥ evamucchanīyaḥ iti
translated: ‘This is a conch shell, sirs, the sound of which is so captivating, so delightful, so intoxicating, so compelling, so enticing.’

original: Te taṁ saṅkhaṁ uttānaṁ nipātesuṁ:
analyzed: te tam saṅkham uttānam nipātesu
translated: They laid the conch shell on its back and said:

original: ‘vadehi, bho saṅkha, vadehi, bho saṅkhā’ti.
analyzed: vadehi bho saṅkha vadehi bho saṅkha ati
translated: ‘Blow, sir, blow!’

original: Neva so saṅkho saddamakāsi.
analyzed: na iva saḥ saṅkhaḥ saddam akāsi
translated: But the conch shell made no sound.

original: Te taṁ saṅkhaṁ avakujjaṁ nipātesuṁ, passena nipātesuṁ, dutiyena passena nipātesuṁ,🔽uddhaṁ ṭhapesuṁ, omuddhakaṁ ṭhapesuṁ, pāṇinā ākoṭesuṁ, leḍḍunā ākoṭesuṁ, daṇḍena
analyzed: te tam saṅkham avakujjam nipātesu passena nipātesu dutiyena passena nipātesu  uddham ṭhapesu omuddhakam ṭhapesu pāṇinā ākoṭesu leḍḍunā ākoṭesu daṇḍena
translated: They laid the conch shell on its side, on its other side,🔽upright, upside down, they beat it with their hands, with clods of earth, with sticks,

original: ākoṭesuṁ, satthena ākoṭesuṁ, odhuniṁsu sandhuniṁsu niddhuniṁsu:
analyzed: ākoṭesu satthena ākoṭesu odhunisu sandhunisu niddhunisu
translated: with swords, they shook it, they rattled it, they banged it:

original: ‘vadehi, bho saṅkha, vadehi, bho saṅkhā’ti.
analyzed: vadehi bho saṅkha vadehi bho saṅkha ati
translated: ‘Blow, sir, blow!’

original: Neva so saṅkho saddamakāsi.
analyzed: na iva saḥ saṅkhaḥ saddam akāsi
translated: But the conch shell made no sound.

original: Atha kho, rājañña, tassa saṅkhadhamassa etadahosi:
analyzed: atha kho rājañña tassa saṅkhadhamassa etat ahosi
translated: Then the idea occurred to him:

original: ‘yāva bālā ime paccantajanapadā manussā, kathañhi nāma ayoniso saṅkhasaddaṁ gavesissantī’ti.
analyzed: yāva bālāḥ ime paccanta janapadāḥ manussā katham hi nāma ayonisaḥ saṅkha saddam gavesissanti iti
translated: ‘How foolish and ignorant are these people in the provinces! How can they search for the sound of a conch as if it were a thing external to the conch itself?’

original: Tesaṁ pekkhamānānaṁ saṅkhaṁ gahetvā tikkhattuṁ saṅkhaṁ upalāpetvā saṅkhaṁ ādāya pakkāmi.
analyzed: tesam pekkhamānānam saṅkham gahetvā tikkhattum saṅkham upalāpetvā saṅkham ādāya pakkāmi
translated: And while they were looking on, he took the conch, blew it three times, and then went away with it.

original: Atha kho, rājañña, tesaṁ paccantajanapadānaṁ manussānaṁ etadahosi:🔽‘yadā kira, bho, ayaṁ saṅkho nāma purisasahagato ca hoti vāyāmasahagato ca vāyusahagato🔽ca, tadāyaṁ saṅkho saddaṁ karoti, yadā panāyaṁ saṅkho neva purisasahagato hoti na
analyzed: atha kho rājañña tesam paccanta janapadānam manussānam etat ahosi  yadā kira bho ayam saṅkhaḥ nāma purisa sahagataḥ ca hoti vāyāma sahagataḥ ca vāyu sahagataḥ  ca tadā ayam saṅkho saddam karoti yadā pana ayam saṅkhaḥ na iva purisa sahagataḥ hoti na
translated: Then the idea occurred to them:

original: vāyāmasahagato na vāyusahagato, nāyaṁ saṅkho saddaṁ karotī’ti.
analyzed: vāyāma sahagataḥ na vāyu sahagataḥ na ayam saṅkhaḥ saddam karoti iti
translated: ‘When this conch is accompanied by a man, accompanied by effort, accompanied by breath, then it makes a sound. But when it is not accompanied by a man, not accompanied by effort, not accompanied by breath, then it makes no sound.’

original: Evameva kho, rājañña, yadāyaṁ kāyo āyusahagato ca hoti usmāsahagato ca viññāṇasahagato
analyzed: evam eva kho rājañña yadā ayam kāyo āyu sahagataḥ ca hoti usmā sahagataḥ ca viññāṇa sahagataḥ
translated: So too, Prince, when this body is accompanied by life, accompanied by heat, accompanied by consciousness,

original: ca, tadā abhikkamatipi paṭikkamatipi tiṭṭhatipi nisīdatipi seyyampi kappeti, cakkhunāpi🔽rūpaṁ passati, sotenapi saddaṁ suṇāti, ghānenapi gandhaṁ ghāyati, jivhāyapi rasaṁ
analyzed: ca tadā abhikkamati pi paṭikkamati pi tiṭṭhati pi nisīdati pi seyyam pi kappeti cakkhunā api  rūpam passati sotena api saddam suṇāti ghānena api gandham ghāyati jivhāya api
translated: and then he goes forward and goes back, he stands and sits and lies down, he sees forms with the eye,🔽he hears sounds with the ear, he smells smells with the nose, he tastes tastes with the tongue,

original: sāyati, kāyenapi phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusati, manasāpi dhammaṁ vijānāti.
analyzed: sā ayati kāyena api phoṭṭhabbam phusati manasā api dhammam vijānāti
translated: and then it goes forward and back, stands and sits and lies down, and with the eye it sees forms, with the ear it hears sounds, with the nose it smells smells, with the tongue it tastes tastes, with the body it feels touchables, with the mind it knows mind-objects.

original: Yadā panāyaṁ kāyo neva āyusahagato hoti, na usmāsahagato, na viññāṇasahagato, tadā🔽neva abhikkamati na paṭikkamati na tiṭṭhati na nisīdati na seyyaṁ kappeti, cakkhunāpi🔽rūpaṁ na passati, sotenapi saddaṁ na suṇāti, ghānenapi gandhaṁ na ghāyati, jivhāyapi
analyzed: yadā pana ayam kāyaḥ na iva āyu sahagataḥ hoti na usmā sahagataḥ na viññāṇa sahagataḥ tadā  na iva abhikkamati na paṭikkamati na tiṭṭhati na nisīdati na seyyam kappeti cakkhunā api  rūpam na passati sotena api saddam na suṇāti ghānena api gandham na ghāyati jivhāya api
translated: But when this body is not endowed with life, not endowed with heat, not endowed with consciousness,

original: rasaṁ na sāyati, kāyenapi phoṭṭhabbaṁ na phusati, manasāpi dhammaṁ na vijānāti.
analyzed: rasam na sāyati kāyena api phoṭṭhabbam na phusati manasā api dhammam na vijānāti
translated: then it does not go forward and back, stand and sit and lie down, and with the eye it does not see forms, with the ear it does not hear sounds, with the nose it does not smell smells, with the tongue it does not taste tastes, with the body it does not feel touchables, with the mind it does not know mind-objects.

original: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
analyzed: iminā api kho te rājañña pariyāyena evam hotu
translated: In this way too, Prince, this should not be the case for you:

original: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.🔽“Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
analyzed: iti pi atthi paraḥ lokaḥ atthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ atthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti  kiñca api bhavam kassapaḥ evam āha atha kho evam me ettha hoti
translated: “There is another world … there are spontaneously born beings … there is fruit and result of good and bad actions.”

original: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
analyzed: iti pi natthi paraḥ lokaḥ natthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I think there is no other world … there is no fruit and result of good and bad actions.”

original: “Atthi pana, rājañña, pariyāyo …pe…
analyzed: atthi pana rājañña pariyāyaḥ pe
translated: “Then, Prince, I ask the Prince this:

original: atthi, bho kassapa, pariyāyo …pe…
analyzed: atthi bho kassapa pariyāyaḥ pe
translated: “There is, Master Kassapa.”

original: yathā kathaṁ viya, rājaññā”ti?🔽“Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṁ āgucāriṁ gahetvā dassenti:
analyzed: yathā katham viya  idha me bho kassapa purisā coram āgu cārim gahetvā dassenti
translated: “Then, Prince, in what way do you think there is another world … there is fruit and result of good and bad actions?”🔽“Master Kassapa, they bring a thief caught in the act before you

original: ‘ayaṁ te, bhante, coro āgucārī,
analyzed: ayam te bhante coraḥ āgu cārī
translated: and say: ‘Sir, this is a thief caught in the act.

original: imassa yaṁ icchasi, taṁ daṇḍaṁ paṇehī’ti.
analyzed: imassa yam icchasi tam daṇḍam paṇehi iti
translated: Impose on him whatever punishment you wish.’

original: Tyāhaṁ evaṁ vadāmi:
analyzed: tya aham evam vadāmi
translated: I say to them:

original: ‘tena hi, bho, imassa purisassa chaviṁ chindatha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
analyzed: tena hi bho imassa purisassa chavim chindatha appā iva nāmassa jīvam passeyyāma ati
translated: ‘Sirs, cut open this man’s skin. Perhaps we can see his soul.’

original: Te tassa purisassa chaviṁ chindanti.
analyzed: te tassa purisassa chavim chindanti
translated: They cut open the man’s skin,

original: Nevassa mayaṁ jīvaṁ passāma.
analyzed: na iva assa mayam jīvam passāma
translated: but we don’t see his soul.

original: Tyāhaṁ evaṁ vadāmi:
analyzed: tya aham evam vadāmi
translated: I say to them:

original: ‘tena hi, bho, imassa purisassa cammaṁ chindatha, maṁsaṁ chindatha, nhāruṁ chindatha, aṭṭhiṁ chindatha, aṭṭhimiñjaṁ chindatha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
analyzed: tena hi bho imassa purisassa cammam chindatha masam chindatha nhārum chindatha aṭṭhim chindatha aṭṭhimiñjam chindatha appā iva nāmassa jīvam passeyyāma iti
translated: ‘Well then, gentlemen, cut the skin of this man, cut the flesh, cut the sinews, cut the bones, cut the bone-marrow, and perhaps we will see his life.’

original: Te tassa purisassa aṭṭhimiñjaṁ chindanti, nevassa mayaṁ jīvaṁ passeyyāma.
analyzed: te tassa purisassa aṭṭhimiñjam chindanti na iva assa mayam jīvam passeyyāma
translated: They cut the bone-marrow of this man, but we did not see his life.

original: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: ayam pi kho bho kassapa pariyāyaḥ yena me pariyāyena evam hoti
translated: This is the way, Master Kassapa, in which I understand the Dhamma taught by Master Kassapa to be.

original: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
analyzed: iti pi natthi paraḥ lokaḥ natthi sattāḥ opapātikāḥ natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam vipāko ti
translated: So I conclude that there is no other world, that beings are not reborn, and that there is no fruit or result of good or bad deeds.’

original: 2.10. Aggikajaṭilaupamā
analyzed: aggika jaṭila aupamā
translated: .. The Simile of the Hair-Whorl

original: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi.
analyzed: tena hi rājaññaḥ upamam te karissāmi
translated: “Well now, Prince, I will give you a simile.

original: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.🔽Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññataro aggiko jaṭilo araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭiyā sammati.
analyzed: upamāya midhekacce viññū purisāḥ bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti  bhūta pubba rājañña aññataraḥ aggikaḥ jaṭilaḥ arañña āyatane paṇṇa kuṭiyā sammati
translated: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.🔽Prince, once upon a time a certain hair-whorl ascetic was living in some forest.

original: Atha kho, rājañña, aññataro janapade sattho vuṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: atha kho rājañña aññataraḥ janapade satthaḥ vuṭṭhāsi
translated: Then, Prince, a certain caravan left the highway and went by a side-road.

original: Atha kho so sattho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa assamassa sāmantā ekarattiṁ vasitvā pakkāmi.
analyzed: atha kho saḥ satthaḥ tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa assamassa sāmantā eka rattim vasitvā pakkāmi
translated: Then, after spending one night near the hermitage of the fire-worshipper, the caravan left.

original: Atha kho, rājañña, tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa etadahosi:
analyzed: atha kho rājañña tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa etat ahosi
translated: Then the fire-worshipper thought:

original: ‘yannūnāhaṁ yena so satthavāso tenupasaṅkameyyaṁ, appeva nāmettha kiñci upakaraṇaṁ adhigaccheyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham yena saḥ satthavāso tena upasaṅkameyya appa eva nāma ittha kiñci upakaraṇam adhigaccheyyanti
translated: ‘Why don’t I go to that caravan and see if I can get anything useful there?’

original: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo kālasseva vuṭṭhāya yena so satthavāso tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā addasa tasmiṁ satthavāse daharaṁ kumāraṁ mandaṁ uttānaseyyakaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ.
analyzed: atha kho saḥ aggikaḥ jaṭilaḥ kālassa iva vuṭṭhāya yena saḥ satthavāso tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā addasa tasmin satthavāse daharam kumāram mandam uttānaseyyakam chaḍḍita
translated: So he got up early and went to the caravan, where he saw a young boy, small, with a head like a mushroom, abandoned.

original: Disvānassa etadahosi:
analyzed: disvānassa etat ahosi
translated: He thought:

original: ‘na kho me taṁ patirūpaṁ yaṁ me pekkhamānassa manussabhūto kālaṅkareyya;
analyzed: na kho me tam patirūpam yam me pekkhamānassa manussa bhūtaḥ kālaṅkareyya
translated: ‘It wouldn’t be right for me to just stand by and watch a human being die.

original: yannūnāhaṁ imaṁ dārakaṁ assamaṁ netvā āpādeyyaṁ poseyyaṁ vaḍḍheyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham imam dārakam assamam netvā āpādeyyam poseyyam vaḍḍheyyanti
translated: Why don’t I take him to my hermitage and raise him?’

original: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo taṁ dārakaṁ assamaṁ netvā āpādesi posesi vaḍḍhesi.
analyzed: atha kho saḥ aggikaḥ jaṭilaḥ tam dārakam assamam netvā āpādesi posesi vaḍḍhesi
translated: So he took the boy to his hermitage and raised him.

original: Yadā so dārako dasavassuddesiko vā hoti dvādasavassuddesiko vā, atha kho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa janapade kañcideva karaṇīyaṁ uppajji.
analyzed: yadā saḥ dārakaḥ dasa vassuddesikaḥ vā hoti dvādasa vassuddesikaḥ vā atha kho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa janapade kañcid eva karaṇīyam uppajji
translated: When the boy was ten or twelve years old, the ascetic went to the countryside on some business.

original: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo taṁ dārakaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho saḥ aggikaḥ jaṭilaḥ tam dārakam etat avoca
translated: He said to the boy,

original: ‘icchāmahaṁ, tāta, janapadaṁ gantuṁ;
analyzed: icchāmaha tāta janapadam gantu
translated: ‘Son, I want to go to the countryside.

translated: Throw away the old grass, sticks, and water, and go quickly with light carts, so that the oxen do not get tired.’

translated: ‘This man says

analyzed: puratas kantāre mahā meghaḥ abhippavuṭṭhaḥ āsitta udakāni vaṭumāni bahu tiṇam ca kaṭṭhañca udakañca

original: Chaḍḍetha, bho, purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni, lahubhārehi sakaṭehi sīghaṁ sīghaṁ gacchatha; mā yoggāni kilamitthā”ti.
analyzed: chaḍḍetha bho purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni lahu bhārehi sakaṭehi sīgham sīgham gacchatha mā yoggāni kilamittha ati
translated: Throw away the old grass, sticks, and water, and go quickly with light carts, so that the oxen do not get tired.’

original: Ayaṁ bho puriso neva amhākaṁ mitto, na ñātisālohito, kathaṁ mayaṁ imassa saddhāya gamissāma.
analyzed: ayam bho purisaḥ na iva amhākam mittaḥ na ñāti sālohito katham mayam imassa saddhāya gamissāma
translated: But this man is neither our friend nor relative, so how can we trust him?

original: Na vo chaḍḍetabbāni purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni, yathābhatena bhaṇḍena satthaṁ payāpetha.
analyzed: na vaḥ chaḍḍetabbāni purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni yathābhatena bhaṇḍena sattham payāpetha

translated: But on the first camping place they didn’t see any grass, sticks, or water.

original: Dutiyepi satthavāse …

original: chaṭṭhepi satthavāse …

translated: on the sixth …

analyzed: sattame pi satthavāse na tiṇam vā kaṭṭham vā udakam vā

original: Tañca satthaṁ addasaṁsu anayabyasanaṁ āpannaṁ.
analyzed: tat ca sattham addasasu anaya byasanam āpanna
translated: And they saw that the caravan had been destroyed.

original: Ye ca tasmiṁ satthepi ahesuṁ manussā vā pasū vā, tesañca aṭṭhikāneva addasaṁsu tena yakkhena amanussena bhakkhitānaṁ.
analyzed: ye ca tasmin satthe pi ahesum manussāḥ vā pasū vā tesam ca aṭṭhikāna eva addasasu tena yakkhena amanussena bhakkhitāna
translated: And they saw the bones of the people and animals that had been eaten by that non-human spirit.

original: Atha kho so satthavāho satthike āmantesi:

translated: ‘This caravan has come to ruin and destruction through the fault of that foolish leader.

original: Tena hi, bho, yānamhākaṁ satthe appasārāni paṇiyāni, tāni chaḍḍetvā, yāni imasmiṁ satthe mahāsārāni paṇiyāni, tāni ādiyathā’ti.
analyzed: tena hi bho satthe appasārāni paṇiyāni tāni chaḍḍetvā yāni imasmin satthe mahā sārāni paṇiyāni tāni ādiyatha ati
translated: So let us abandon the inferior goods in our caravan and take the better ones from the other caravan.’

original: ‘Evaṁ, bho’ti kho te satthikā tassa satthavāhassa paṭissutvā yāni sakasmiṁ satthe🔽appasārāni paṇiyāni, tāni chaḍḍetvā yāni tasmiṁ satthe mahāsārāni paṇiyāni, tāni🔽ādiyitvā sotthinā taṁ kantāraṁ nitthariṁsu, yathā taṁ paṇḍitena satthavāhena pariṇāyakena.

translated: ‘Very well,’ they said, and they did so. And they safely crossed the desert,🔽just as the wise leader of the second caravan had advised.

original: Evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, bālo abyatto anayabyasanaṁ āpajjissasi ayoniso paralokaṁ gavesanto, seyyathāpi so purimo satthavāho.

original: Yepi tava sotabbaṁ saddhātabbaṁ maññissanti, tepi anayabyasanaṁ āpajjissanti, seyyathāpi te satthikā.
analyzed: ye pi tava sotabbam saddhātabbam maññissanti te pi anaya byasanam āpajjissanti seyyathā api te satthikā
translated: Those who think they should listen to you and place their confidence in you will also come to ruin and destruction, just like those five hundred young brahmins.

original: Paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ; paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ.
analyzed: paṭinissajjeta rājañña pāpakam diṭṭhigata paṭinissajjeta rājañña pāpakam diṭṭhigata

original: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
analyzed: mā te ahosi dīgharattam ahitāya dukkhāya ati
translated: Don’t let it cause you harm and suffering for a long time.”

translated: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I’m not able to give up this bad perception.

analyzed: rājā api mam pasenadi kosalaḥ jānāti rājaññaḥ eva vādī eva diṭṭhī
translated: King Pasenadi of Kosala knows me as one who says this and holds this view:

original: “itipi natthi paro loko …pe… vipāko”’ti.

translated: ‘There is no other world … and there are no results of good and bad actions.’

analyzed: sacā āha bho kassapa idam pāpakam diṭṭhi gatam paṭinissajjissāmi bhavissanti me vattāro
translated: If I give up this bad perception, people will say:

analyzed: yāva bālaḥ pāyāsi rājaññaḥ abyattaḥ duggahita gāhī iti
translated: ‘The aristocrat Pāyāsi is a fool, confused, misguided, and of wrong view.’

original: Kopenapi naṁ harissāmi, makkhenapi naṁ harissāmi, palāsenapi naṁ harissāmī”ti.
analyzed: kopena api nam harissāmi makkhena api nam harissāmi palāsena api nam harissāmi iti
translated: I’ll have to carry him off on a litter, or else carry him off on a litter of poles.”

original: 2.12. Gūthabhārikaupamā

translated: 2.12. The simile of the dung-bearer

original: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi.

translated: Some wise people understand the meaning of what is said by way of similes.

analyzed: bhūta pubba rājañña aññataro sūkara posako puriso sakamhā gāmā aññam gāmam agamāsi
translated: Prince, once upon a time there was a pig-keeper who went from his own village to another village.

original: Tattha addasa pahūtaṁ sukkhagūthaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ.

original: Disvānassa etadahosi:

translated: He spread out his upper robe, filled it with the dry dung, tied it up in a bundle, put it on his head, and went on his way.

original: Tassa antarāmagge mahāakālamegho pāvassi.

translated: But on the road a great storm-cloud rained down.

translated: When people saw him, they said:

translated: ‘Are you mad, sir? Are you out of your mind? How can you carry a load of dung dripping and leaking up to the top of the nails on your feet?’

original: ‘Tumhe khvettha, bhaṇe, ummattā, tumhe vicetā, tathā hi pana me sūkarabhattan’ti.
analyzed: tumhe khvettha bhaṇe ummattā tumhe vicetā tathā hi pana me
translated: ‘You’re the mad ones, sir, you’re the ones out of your mind! This is my food for the pigs!’

original: Evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, gūthabhārikūpamo maññe paṭibhāsi.
analyzed: evam eva kho tva rājañña gūtha bhārikū pamaḥ maññe paṭibhāsi
translated: In the same way, Prince, you seem to be like the man carrying dung.

analyzed: kiñca api bhavam kassapaḥ evam āha atha kho na iva aham sakkomi idam pāpakam diṭṭhi gatam paṭinissajjitu
translated: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I can’t let go of this bad perception,

analyzed: pāyāsi rājaññaḥ eva vādī eva diṭṭhī
translated: ‘Prince Payasi holds this view, this belief:

analyzed: iti pi natthi paraḥ loko pe vipāko ti
translated: “There is no other world … and there are no results of good and bad deeds.”’

analyzed: sacā āha bho kassapa idam pāpakam diṭṭhi gatam paṭinissajjissāmi bhavissanti me vattāro
translated: If I give up this evil viewpoint, they will say:

translated: ‘The aristocrat Pāyāsi is a fool, incompetent, and incapable of answering the ascetic Gotama’s questions.

translated: I will carry him out on a litter if he walks, and if he rides, I will go along too.’

translated: for with the help of a simile some intelligent people understand the meaning of what is said.

translated: Once upon a time, prince, two gamblers were playing dice.

translated: ‘You keep on winning, my dear, so give me the dice and I will stop playing.’

original: ‘Evaṁ, sammā’ti kho so akkhadhutto tassa akkhadhuttassa akkhe pādāsi.

translated: ‘Come on, let’s play.’

original: ‘Evaṁ, sammā’ti kho so akkhadhutto tassa akkhadhuttassa paccassosi.
analyzed: eva sammā iti kho so akkhadhutto tassa akkhadhuttassa paccassosi

translated: Swallow, you cheat, swallow!

analyzed: pacchā te kaṭukam bhavissati iti  evam eva kho tva rājañña akkhadhuttaka upamaḥ maññe paṭibhāsi
translated: It’ll be bitter for you later.’🔽In the same way, Prince, you seem to be like the cheat with the dice.

original: Paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ; paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ.
analyzed: paṭinissajjeta rājañña pāpakam diṭṭhigata paṭinissajjeta rājañña pāpakam diṭṭhigata
translated: Give up this bad perception, Prince. Give up this bad perception.

original: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
analyzed: mā te ahosi dīgharattam ahitāya dukkhāya ati
translated: May it not be for your long-lasting harm and suffering!”

original: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho nevāhaṁ sakkomi idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjituṁ.
analyzed: kiñca api bhavam kassapaḥ evam āha atha kho na iva aham sakkomi idam pāpakam diṭṭhi gatam paṭinissajjitu
translated: “Although Master Kassapa says this, still I am not able to abandon this evil viewpoint.

original: Rājāpi maṁ pasenadi kosalo jānāti tirorājānopi:
analyzed: rājā api mam pasenadi kosalaḥ jānāti
translated: King Pasenadi of Kosala knows me as one who holds this view, and so do the kings and rulers abroad.

original: ‘pāyāsi rājañño evaṁvādī evaṁdiṭṭhī:
analyzed: pāyāsi rājaññaḥ eva vādī eva diṭṭhī
translated: ‘The brahmin Pangnāga is one who holds this view and declares it thus:

original: “itipi natthi paro loko …pe… vipāko”’ti.
analyzed: iti pi natthi paraḥ loko pe vipāko ti
translated: “There is no other world… nor do beings reappear in another world after death”…

original: Sacāhaṁ, bho kassapa, idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjissāmi, bhavissanti me vattāro:
analyzed: sacā āha bho kassapa idam pāpakam diṭṭhi gatam paṭinissajjissāmi bhavissanti me vattāro
translated: If I were to abandon this evil viewpoint, people would say:

original: ‘yāva bālo pāyāsi rājañño abyatto duggahitagāhī’ti.
analyzed: yāva bālaḥ pāyāsi rājaññaḥ abyattaḥ duggahita gāhī iti
translated: ‘Pangnāga the brahmin has been refuted, countered, and driven to silence by Kassapa the contemplative.’🔽I would be subject to criticism, and that would not be good.

original: Kopenapi naṁ harissāmi, makkhenapi naṁ harissāmi, palāsenapi naṁ harissāmī”ti.
analyzed: kopena api nam harissāmi makkhena api nam harissāmi palāsena api nam harissāmi iti
translated: I would be subject to criticism, and that would not be good.”

original: 2.14. Sāṇabhārikaupamā
analyzed: sāṇabhārikā aupamā
translated: The Simile of the Bundle of Reeds

original: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi,
analyzed: tena hi rājaññaḥ upamam te karissāmi
translated: “Well now, Prince, I will give you a simile.

original: upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
analyzed: upamāya midhekacce viññū purisāḥ bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti
translated: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

original: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññataro janapado vuṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: bhūta pubba rājañña aññataraḥ janapadaḥ vuṭṭhāsi
translated: Prince, there was an occasion when a certain country was deserted.

original: Atha kho sahāyako sahāyakaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: atha khalu sahāyakaḥ sahāyakam āmantesi
translated: The friend said to his friend,

original: ‘āyāma, samma, yena so janapado tenupasaṅkamissāma, appeva nāmettha kiñci dhanaṁ adhigaccheyyāmā’ti.
analyzed: āyāma samma yena saḥ janapadaḥ tena upasaṅkamissāma appa eva nāma ittha kiñci dhanam adhigaccheyyāma ati
translated: ‘Come, my friend, let’s go to that district, perhaps we can get something there.’

original: ‘Evaṁ, sammā’ti kho sahāyako sahāyakassa paccassosi.
analyzed: eva sammā iti kho sahāyakaḥ sahāyakassa paccassosi
translated: ‘Yes, friend,’ he replied.

original: Te yena so janapado, yena aññataraṁ gāmapaṭṭaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu, tattha addasaṁsu pahūtaṁ sāṇaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: te yena saḥ janapadaḥ yena aññataram gāma paṭṭam tena upasaṅkamisu tattha pahūtam sāṇam chaḍḍita disvā sahāyakaḥ sahāyakam āmantesi
translated: They went to that district and to a certain village. There they saw a lot of hemp that had been thrown away. Seeing it, the friend said to his friend,

original: ‘idaṁ kho, samma, pahūtaṁ sāṇaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṁ bandha, ahañca sāṇabhāraṁ bandhissāmi, ubho sāṇabhāraṁ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
analyzed: idam kho samma pahūtam sāṇam chaḍḍita tena hi samma tvam ca sāṇa bhāram bandha aham ca sāṇa bhāram bandhissāmi ubho sāṇa bhāram ādāya gamissāma ati
translated: ‘My friend, here’s a lot of hemp that’s been thrown away. Well then, my friend, you tie up a bundle of hemp and I’ll tie up a bundle of hemp. We’ll both take a bundle of hemp and go.’

original: ‘Evaṁ, sammā’ti kho sahāyako sahāyakassa paṭissutvā sāṇabhāraṁ bandhitvā te ubho sāṇabhāraṁ ādāya yena aññataraṁ gāmapaṭṭaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu.
analyzed: eva sammā iti kho sahāyakaḥ sahāyakassa paṭissutvā sāṇa bhāram bandhitvā te ubho sāṇa bhāram ādāya yena aññataram gāma paṭṭam tena upasaṅkamisu
translated: ‘Yes, friend,’ he replied. He tied up a bundle of hemp. They both took a bundle of hemp and went to a certain village.

original: Tattha addasaṁsu pahūtaṁ sāṇasuttaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: tattha pahūtam sāṇa suttam disvā sahāyakaḥ sahāyakam āmantesi
translated: There they saw a lot of hempen thread that had been thrown away. Seeing it, the one friend said to the other,

original: ‘yassa kho, samma, atthāya iccheyyāma sāṇaṁ, idaṁ pahūtaṁ sāṇasuttaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ.
analyzed: yassa kho samma atthāya iccheyyāma sāṇa idam pahūtam sāṇa suttam chaḍḍita
translated: ‘Friend, for the sake of which we wanted hemp, this lot of hempen thread has been thrown away.

original: Tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍehi, ahañca sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍessāmi, ubho sāṇasuttabhāraṁ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
analyzed: tena hi samma tvañca sāṇa bhāram chaḍḍehi ahañca sāṇa bhāram chaḍḍessāmi ubho sāṇa sutta bhāram ādāya gamissāma ati
translated: Well then, friend, you throw away your load of hemp, and I’ll throw away my load of hemp, and we’ll both take a load of hempen thread and go.’

original: ‘Ayaṁ kho me, samma, sāṇabhāro dūrābhato ca susannaddho ca, alaṁ me, tvaṁ pajānāhī’ti.
analyzed: ayam kho me samma sāṇabhāraḥ dūra ābhataḥ ca su sannaddhaḥ ca alam me tvam pajānāhi iti
translated: ‘This load of hemp of mine is heavy, and I’ve carried it a long way. I’ll carry it on. You do as you like.’

original: Atha kho so sahāyako sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍetvā sāṇasuttabhāraṁ ādiyi.
analyzed: atha kho saḥ sahāyakaḥ sāṇa bhāram chaḍḍetvā sāṇa sutta bhāram ādiyi
translated: So the one friend threw away his load of hemp and took a load of hempen thread.

original: Te yena aññataraṁ gāmapaṭṭaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu.
analyzed: te yena aññataram gāma paṭṭam tena upasaṅkamisu
translated: They went to a certain village.

original: Tattha addasaṁsu pahūtā sāṇiyo chaḍḍitā, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: tattha addasasu pahūtā sāṇiyaḥ chaḍḍitā disvā sahāyakaḥ sahāyakam āmantesi
translated: There they saw a lot of hempen cloth that had been thrown away. Seeing it, the one friend said to the other,

original: ‘yassa kho, samma, atthāya iccheyyāma sāṇaṁ vā sāṇasuttaṁ vā, imā pahūtā sāṇiyo chaḍḍitā.
analyzed: yassa kho samma atthāya iccheyyāma sāṇam vā sāṇa suttam vā imā pahūtā sāṇiyaḥ chaḍḍitā
translated: ‘Friend, for the sake of which we wanted hemp or hempen thread, this lot of hempen cloth has been thrown away.

original: Tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍehi, ahañca sāṇasuttabhāraṁ chaḍḍessāmi, ubho sāṇibhāraṁ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
analyzed: tena hi samma tvañca sāṇa bhāram chaḍḍehi ahañca sāṇa sutta bhāram chaḍḍessāmi ubho sāṇi bhāram ādāya gamissāma ati
translated: ‘Well then, friend, you throw away your load of hemp, and I’ll throw away my load of hemp-thread, and we’ll both take a load of hemp and go.’

original: ‘Ayaṁ kho me, samma, sāṇabhāro dūrābhato ca susannaddho ca, alaṁ me, tvaṁ pajānāhī’ti.
analyzed: ayam kho me samma sāṇabhāraḥ dūra ābhataḥ ca su sannaddhaḥ ca alam me tvam pajānāhi iti
translated: ‘This load of hemp of mine is heavy enough, and I’ve carried it a long way. I’ll take it myself.’

original: Atha kho so sahāyako sāṇasuttabhāraṁ chaḍḍetvā sāṇibhāraṁ ādiyi.

translated: So his friend threw away his load of hemp-thread and took a load of hemp.

translated: They went to a certain market town,

translated: a lot of linen-cloth thrown away,🔽a lot of cotton thrown away,🔽a lot of cotton-thread thrown away,

analyzed: pahūtam loham chaḍḍita disvā  pahūtam tipum chaḍḍita disvā
translated: a lot of cotton-cloth thrown away,🔽a lot of iron thrown away,🔽a lot of tin thrown away,

translated: a lot of lead thrown away,

translated: and a lot of gold. He said to his friend, ‘We can get what we need from hemp, hemp thread, hemp cloth, cotton,🔽cotton thread, cotton cloth, linen,

translated: linen thread, linen cloth, iron, tin, lead, or copper.🔽But this gold has been discarded.

translated: So you discard your load of hemp, I’ll discard my load of copper, and we’ll both take a load of gold.’

analyzed: ayam kho me samma sāṇabhāraḥ dūra ābhataḥ ca su sannaddhaḥ ca alam me tvam pajānāhi iti
translated: ‘This load of hemp has been carried a long way and is well tied. You can take it.’

translated: So his friend discarded his load of copper and took a load of gold.

translated: They then went to their own village.

translated: There his friend who had brought a load of hemp was neither greeted by his parents,

translated: nor by his wife and children, nor by his friends and companions, nor did he get any pleasure from it.

translated: But his friend who had brought a load of gold was greeted by his parents, by his wife and children, by his friends and companions, and he got much pleasure from it.

analyzed: evam eva kho tva rājañña sāṇabhārikū pamaḥ maññe paṭibhāsi
translated: In the same way, Prince, you seem to be like the man who brought a load of hemp.

original: Paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ; paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ.
analyzed: paṭinissajjeta rājañña pāpakam diṭṭhigata paṭinissajjeta rājañña pāpakam diṭṭhigata
translated: Give up this evil viewpoint, Prince, give up this evil viewpoint.

original: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
analyzed: mā te ahosi dīgharattam ahitāya dukkhāya ati
translated: Do not let it lead to your long-term harm, unhappiness and suffering.”

original: 3. Saraṇagamana
analyzed: saraṇa gamana
translated: Taking Refuge

original: “Purimeneva ahaṁ opammena bhoto kassapassa attamano abhiraddho.
analyzed: purimena iva aham opammena bhoto kassapassa atta manaḥ abhiraddhaḥ
translated: “I am satisfied and pleased with what the Reverend Kassapa says.

original: Api cāhaṁ imāni vicitrāni pañhāpaṭibhānāni sotukāmo evāhaṁ bhavantaṁ kassapaṁ paccanīkaṁ kātabbaṁ amaññissaṁ.

translated: But I thought, ‘I will ask the ascetic Kassapa these various questions.’

original: Abhikkantaṁ, bho kassapa, abhikkantaṁ, bho kassapa.🔽Seyyathāpi, bho kassapa, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa
analyzed: abhikkanta bho kassapa abhikkanta bho kassapa  seyyathā api bho kassapa nikkujjitam vā ukkujjeyya paṭicchannam vā vivareyya mūḷhassa
translated: Excellent, Master Kassapa! Excellent, Master Kassapa!

original: vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti;
analyzed: vā maggam ācikkheyya andhakāre vā tela pajjotam dhāreyya cakkhumantaḥ rūpāni dakkhanti iti
translated: Just as if he were to place upright what was overturned, to reveal what was hidden, to show the way to one who was lost, or to carry a lamp into the dark so that those with eyes could see forms,

original: evamevaṁ bhotā kassapena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
analyzed: evam evam bhotā kassapena aneka pariyāyena dhammo pakāsito
translated: in the same way has Master Kassapa - through many lines of reasoning - made the Dhamma clear.

original: Esāhaṁ, bho kassapa, taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi, dhammañca, bhikkhusaṅghañca.
analyzed: esā aha bho kassapa tam bhavantam gotamam saraṇam gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhu saṅghañca
translated: I go to Master Kassapa for refuge and to the Dhamma and to the Sangha of bhikkhus.

original: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ kassapo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gataṁ.
analyzed: upāsakam mam bhavam kassapaḥ dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇa upetam saraṇam gata
translated: May Master Kassapa regard me as a lay follower who from today has gone for refuge for life.

original: Icchāmi cāhaṁ, bho kassapa, mahāyaññaṁ yajituṁ, anusāsatu maṁ bhavaṁ kassapo, yaṁ mamassa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
analyzed: icchāmi ca āha bho kassapa mahāyaññam yajitu anusāsatu mama bhavam kassapaḥ yam mama assa dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya ati
translated: Master Kassapa, I wish to make a great sacrifice. May Master Kassapa advise me, out of compassion, so as to ensure my lasting welfare and happiness.”

original: 4. Yaññakathā
analyzed: yañ ña kathā
translated: The Discussion of the Sacrifice

analyzed: yathārūpe kho rājañña yaññe gāvaḥ vā haññanti ajeḍakāḥ vā haññanti kukkuṭa sūkarā  vā haññanti vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātam āpajjanti paṭiggāhakā ca honti micchā diṭṭhī
translated: “Great king, suppose there is a sacrifice at which cattle are slaughtered, goats, sheep, fowl, and pigs are slaughtered,

original: micchāsaṅkappā micchāvācā micchākammantā micchāājīvā micchāvāyāmā micchāsatī micchāsamādhī,
analyzed: micchā saṅkappā micchā vācā micchā kammantā micchā ājīvā micchā vāyāmā micchā satī micchā samādhī
translated: and various kinds of living beings are put to death, and the participants are of wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong concentration.

original: evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño na mahapphalo hoti na mahānisaṁso na mahājutiko na mahāvipphāro.
